meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>need</kanji> something so you <kanji>request</kanji> it. But, since it's such a strong need, it's not really a request, it's more of a <vocabulary>demand</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>leap</kanji> and <kanji>advance</kanji>, you make <vocabulary>rapid progress</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>great advancement</vocabulary>.

You might recall that 飛躍 also means "rapid progress," but what sets them apart? 躍進 emphasizes the subject's perspective as it advances at a rapid pace, whereas 飛躍 conveys significant progress or leaps more neutrally, without highlighting pace or perspective.

Every <kanji>leap</kanji> you take is a <kanji>move</kanji> filled with <vocabulary>vibrancy</vocabulary>. Your <vocabulary>dynamic movement</vocabulary> captures the essence of <vocabulary>lively motion</vocabulary>, captivating all who witness it.

躍動 is not just about movement, but also about expressing internal vitality or liveliness through movements or actions. It’s commonly used as 躍動感 (a lively feeling).

When you <kanji>throw</kanji> out something and <kanji>abandon</kanji> it, you are essentially <vocabulary>dumping</vocabulary> it.

投棄 is a formal word for <vocabulary>throwing away</vocabulary> things, often used in the context of illegally dumping waste.

駆ける is "to gallop" and the kanji 込 means <kanji>into</kanji>. To gallop into a place is <vocabulary>to rush into</vocabulary> it. You can’t gallop slowly, after all.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to seek refuge</vocabulary>, as in hurrying to a place for safety and support.
駆ける is "to gallop" and 出す is "to remove." So if you gallop out to remove yourself you are probably going <vocabulary>to rush out</vocabulary> a little fast. Calm down and slow down, man!
To 駆ける is "to gallop." 回る is "to revolve." So if you're galloping around in a revolving fashion, you are going <vocabulary>to run around</vocabulary>.

Remember how 不孝 is "disobedience to parents"? Well, <kanji>someone</kanji> who shows <kanji>disobedience to parents</kanji> is a <vocabulary>disobedient child</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>unfilial child</vocabulary>.

You know that 不孝 means "disobedience to parents. So, if you add <kanji>parent</kanji>s to it, it just means the same thing. Just a longer version of the word, basically. This means <vocabulary>lack of filial piety</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>disobedience to parents</vocabulary>.

You know that 携帯 means "portable" or "cell phone" or "mobile phone." And then 電話 means "telephone." This is basically just the longer version of simply saying 携帯, making this a <vocabulary>portable phone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cell phone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mobile phone</vocabulary>. It's sort of like the difference between saying "my cell" and "my cell phone," you dig?
最新 is, as you can probably guess, "the newest." So, the newest <kanji>sharp</kanji> thing, is the <vocabulary>cutting edge</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>state of the art</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> <kanji>fly</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sacrifice fly</vocabulary>. In baseball, this is when you hit the ball in the air so the runner can tag up and move up a base.
You know that 透明 is "transparency" or "transparent" - so, if something is not transparent, then it is <vocabulary>opaque</vocabulary>, making this word <vocabulary>opacity</vocabulary>.

Time to <kanji>overcome</kanji> the <kanji>clothes</kanji> of our enemies. They all wear the same kind of clothes (let's say blue clothes) so we know that if we overcome the blue coated people, we will have won. It will be a <vocabulary>conquest</vocabulary>!
If you're <kanji>overcome</kanji> with <kanji>bright</kanji>ness, you'll be able to see all the little fine <vocabulary>detailed</vocabulary> things.
At the <kanji>arrival</kanji> time you will <kanji>arrive</kanji>. This is your <vocabulary>arrival</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>pair</kanji> of <kanji>child</kanji>ren are the same as each other. They're <vocabulary>twins</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>pair</kanji> of <kanji>eyeball</kanji> <kanji>mirror</kanji>s - that's <vocabulary>binoculars</vocabulary>. Binoculars have mirrors in them to allow you to see through the pair of eye holes, which is how this word makes sense.
The <kanji>philosophy</kanji> <kanji>study</kanji> is the study of <vocabulary>philosophy</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You are <kanji>mourning</kanji> your <kanji>fault</kanji>. Because of your fault, you have gotten a <vocabulary>loss</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>forfeit</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>solid</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>solid</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>upright</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>hard</vocabulary>. This word is often used in the figurative sense, as in a solid defence, a serious topic, or an upright person.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fasten</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to fasten</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tie up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tie together</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Fasten</kanji> everything into <kanji>one</kanji>. <vocabulary>All together</vocabulary> in one <vocabulary>batch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>lump</vocabulary>.

If you take the <kanji>whole</kanji> and <kanji>fasten</kanji> it together, you are <vocabulary>summing up</vocabulary> something and creating an <vocabulary>overview</vocabulary> of it.

総括 is a formal word you'll often come across in official meetings or reports. It means pulling together and summing up scattered bits of information — sometimes for a simple overview, like a department budget report, but more often for the sake of evaluating results and planning a future direction.

<kanji>Unite</kanji> something together and <kanji>fasten</kanji> it and you have <vocabulary>unification</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>generalization</vocabulary>. Nowadays this word is used to mean <vocabulary>management</vocabulary> in some contexts too.

The <kanji>fasten</kanji> <kanji>arc</kanji>s are arcs that go around something to fasten these things all together. What are these things? They are (<vocabulary>parentheses</vocabulary>) and [<vocabulary>brackets</vocabulary>].
A <kanji>round</kanji> <kanji>arc</kanji> is, well, the shape of an <vocabulary>arc</vocabulary>. It has that round shape to it, you know?

Because the hiragana ends with a う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>challenge</kanji>, and the verb form means <vocabulary>to challenge someone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take on something difficult</vocabulary>. 

挑む is a relatively formal word for boldly facing a challenge. It has a strong, spirited feel, like a climber saying "I'm taking on Mt. Everest!" You'll come across it in headlines, live sports commentary, anime battle scenes, or even in daily life when someone wants to sound determined and fired up about their big personal goal.

A <kanji>challenge</kanji> for <kanji>war</kanji>? This is <vocabulary>a challenge</vocabulary> worth accepting. After all, we can't give up without at least giving it <vocabulary>a try</vocabulary> or making some kind of <vocabulary>an attempt</vocabulary>.

Note that 挑戦 refers to a challenge not in the sense of a difficult, challenging task, but in the sense of a bold or daring attempt to take on that task — whether that's defeating a formidable foe, performing an impressive feat, or tackling a tricky problem.

My <kanji>challenge</kanji> has made a <kanji>departure</kanji> and is being sent to the enemy. This challenge that I'm sending is a <vocabulary>provocation</vocabulary> to see if they'll take me up on my challenge.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dig</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dig</vocabulary>.

Let's <kanji>departure</kanji> on our <kanji>dig</kanji>ging up of this site. It is more than just digging, we're going somewhere and learning new things with this dig. This is an <vocabulary>excavation</vocabulary>!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hoist</kanji>. But most commonly (and most importantly), this word means <vocabulary>to deep fry</vocabulary>. I guess you can think of it as hoisting that delicious deep-fried food out of the oil.

Of course, 揚げる can also mean <vocabulary>to hoist</vocabulary> (a sail) or <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary> (a flag) depending on the context.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>grip</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to grasp</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>grip</kanji> with your <kanji>hand</kanji> (onto another hand) is a <vocabulary>handshake</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>grip</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is your <vocabulary>grip</vocabulary>, or more specifically your <vocabulary>grip strength</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>handgrip</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shake</kanji> and the verb vocab is <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary>.

When your heart <kanji>move</kanji>s then <kanji>shake</kanji>s, you’re in a state of <vocabulary>emotional turmoil</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unrest</vocabulary>.

動揺 refers to <vocabulary>being emotionally shaken</vocabulary>, or feeling disturbed, agitated, or unsettled.
I <kanji>write</kanji> for <kanji>purification</kanji>. I do this purification writing in my <vocabulary>study</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>den</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>purification</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is the place where you perform purification on people. Who needs the most purification? The dead. Where do you purify them? In a <vocabulary>funeral hall</vocabulary>.

When you do something <kanji>temporarily</kanji>, you're only doing it <vocabulary>for a while</vocabulary>. It's not permanent — however long it lasts, it's just <vocabulary>for some time</vocabulary>.

暫く refers to a stretch of time that's not too long, but not super short either — just somewhere in between. How long, exactly? It kinda depends on the speaker. If it feels like a while to you, then hey, it's a while!

Keep in mind that the kanji form is quite formal, so it's more commonly written in kana, like しばらく.
<kanji>Temporarily</kanji> <kanji>determine</kanji> something. That makes it <vocabulary>tentative</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>temporary</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>untie</kanji> the <kanji>analysis</kanji>, you are really just doing <vocabulary>analysis</vocabulary> to the analysis, if you catch my drift.
You <kanji>divide</kanji> things to then do <kanji>analysis</kanji> on them. We can just call this <vocabulary>analysis</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>analyzing</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>hinge</kanji> <kanji>axis</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>axis</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pivot</vocabulary> where things hinge.

枢軸 is generally used figuratively to describe the <vocabulary>central part</vocabulary> of something important, or the center of power.
The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>hinge</kanji> is the <vocabulary>center</vocabulary> <vocabulary>pivot</vocabulary> point.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Literally, 軸 can refer to a physical <vocabulary>axis</vocabulary>, like the shaft something rotates around. Figuratively, it describes the <vocabulary>pivotal part</vocabulary> of something, like the central figure in a project, the core idea of a discussion, or the core belief that shapes who you are.
It <kanji>hang</kanji>s on an <kanji>axis</kanji> point. The axis opens up, and reveals a <vocabulary>hanging scroll</vocabulary>. This might take a little extra imagination, but I believe in you.
The <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>axis</kanji> is where the <vocabulary>axis</vocabulary> is, of course, but it's also where the <vocabulary>pivot</vocabulary> is too.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>country</kanji> <kanji>pattern</kanji> is the pattern of things a country does. This is the <vocabulary>national character</vocabulary> of a nation.

A <kanji>person</kanji>'s <kanji>pattern</kanji> is the pattern of actions which they take to become who they are. What do they usually do? What is their pattern? This is the same as their <vocabulary>personal character</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>personality</vocabulary>.
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>overnight</kanji> is a <vocabulary>one night's stay</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Two</kanji> <kanji>overnight</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>two-night stay</vocabulary>. In other words, you're <vocabulary>staying for two nights</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>lodge</kanji> where you will stay <kanji>overnight</kanji> is <vocabulary>lodging</vocabulary>. It is where you will <vocabulary>stay the night</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>overnight</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to stay the night</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>slide</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to slide</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to slip</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to glide</vocabulary>. 

滑る is a versatile word that can cover all kinds of actions, like sliding down playground slides, slipping on ice, skiing or skating, and even failing a test or being demoted.
Imagine something <kanji>round</kanji> that <kanji>slide</kanji>s around with no trouble at all. Its movements are so <vocabulary>effortless</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>smooth</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>dry</kanji> <kanji>lagoon</kanji> is a <vocabulary>tidal flat</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>char</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji> is the part you're looking at so hard it burns a little hole in it. Just imagine yourself looking at a single point so hard that it begins to smolder. This is the <vocabulary>focal point</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>focus</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>char</kanji>, but the verb version is <vocabulary>to get burned</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get scorched</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to get charred</vocabulary>.

This is for when something is burned on the surface. Most of the time, 焦げる is the unhappy and accidental kind of burning. You can use 焦げる when your bread is burned in the toaster, for example, or a shirt is scorched and blackened by an iron.

Let's take a look at this <kanji>example</kanji> and <kanji>surround</kanji> it. This example shows the <vocabulary>extent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>scope</vocabulary> of what we're doing, and the line that surrounds it shows how far that scope goes.

An <kanji>imitation</kanji> of an <kanji>example</kanji> is the <vocabulary>exemplification</vocabulary> of something. It is also a <vocabulary>model</vocabulary> of the example of what you're making.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>distract</kanji> and the verb vocab version of this word is <vocabulary>to distract</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to divert</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Distract</kanji> me with a <kanji>twist</kanji> in what we're doing. Just imagine you're working on something. Then, you get distracted by a twist in whatever it is that you're working on. This little twist doesn't destroy everything, but it does cause a <vocabulary>complication</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>confusion</vocabulary>.

I'm going to <kanji>twist</kanji> this <kanji>bullet</kanji> and turn it around on you. You're the one I'm going to <vocabulary>blame</vocabulary>, which is why my blame bullet is twisted back at you.

The kanji is <kanji>rope</kanji> so this word also refers to a <vocabulary>rope</vocabulary>. This can also mean a <vocabulary>sumo champion's belt</vocabulary>, though you'll probably see that meaning a lot less, unless you're a huge sumo fan.

The "<kanji>side</kanji> <kanji>rope</kanji>." This doesn't make much sense. What this is, though (you'll want to look at the reading), is the <vocabulary>Yokozuna</vocabulary>. This is the <vocabulary>Sumo Grand Champion</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>rope</kanji> <kanji>pull</kanji>. Both sides are pulling on the rope. That is a <vocabulary>tug of war</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You learned a while ago that 交通 means "traffic." So what would a traffic <kanji>net</kanji> be? A <vocabulary>traffic network</vocabulary>, or even a <vocabulary>transportation network</vocabulary>!

When you <kanji>pass through</kanji>, you find out what everyone <kanji>believe</kanji>s via a great <kanji>net</kanji> connecting everyone. What is this net? It's a <vocabulary>communication network</vocabulary>! When you think about it, things like telephone networks or the internet are really just big invisible nets that allow beliefs and information to pass through from one person to another.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Though, it also means <vocabulary>chutzpah</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>courage</vocabulary> (besides just being <vocabulary>liver</vocabulary>). Maybe your liver is where your courage is.
If you have the ol' <kanji>liver</kanji> <kanji>flame</kanji> then you probably have <vocabulary>hepatitis</vocabulary>. AUGH! MY LIVER IS ON FIRE.
The <kanji>liver</kanji> <kanji>internal organ</kanji> is your <vocabulary>liver</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Your <kanji>lawn</kanji> of <kanji>life</kanji> is just your <vocabulary>lawn</vocabulary>. Of course it's alive, otherwise it wouldn't be a very good lawn.
The <kanji>east</kanji> <kanji>lawn</kanji> isn't some eastern lawn, it's in reference to the company <vocabulary>Toshiba</vocabulary>. Might be better to look at the reading first for this one.
The <kanji>lawn</kanji> <kanji>grass</kanji> is the <vocabulary>lawn</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>turf</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>wild</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>wild</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary>.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Go To Rack And Ruin

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>wild</kanji> and the verb is <vocabulary>to be stormy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be rough</vocabulary>. If something is wild, like a storm or something, then it will be stormy and rough, after all.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>garbage</kanji> (ゴミ) <kanji>sack</kanji> is a <vocabulary>garbage sack</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>garbage bag</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>luck</kanji> <kanji>sack</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mystery bag</vocabulary>. These are bags that are sold during the New Year's holiday. They contain various goods that are sold for a certain price. You don't know what's in them, but you know the minimum value of it at least. These are known as <vocabulary>mystery sack</vocabulary>s as well.

You have the kanji for <kanji>parent</kanji> combined with 孝行, which you know means "filial piety." If you show filial piety toward your parents… well, it's still <vocabulary>filial piety</vocabulary>. Now it's just extra clear who you're showing that filial devotion to! 

While it may feel kind of redundant, 親孝行 tends to be a little more common than 孝行. It's nice to add "parent" for extra love points, you know?
If 吹く is "to blow" and 出す is "to remove," then you are removing your blowing. You need <vocabulary>to begin to blow</vocabulary> to do that!

You know that 吹く is "to blow" and the kanji 込 means <kanji>into</kanji>. So this word means <vocabulary>to blow in</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to breathe into</vocabulary>, and it can be used both transitively and intransitively.

It can also be used figuratively to mean to breathe into or<vocabulary>to imbue</vocabulary>, like breathing new life into something, or imbuing someone’s mind with hatred.
You know that 口笛 is "whistling." So, if you're <kanji>blow</kanji>ing your whistle you're going <vocabulary>to whistle</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dilute</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to dilute</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to water down</vocabulary>.

You've seen 逃げる and 逃す. This one is 逃れる. This one simply means <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>. So that's not too bad. The difference between this one and the other escapes is that it has to do more with luck.
You know that 吹く is "to blow" and that 飛ばす is "To let fly." So, if you use your blowing to let something fly, you are going <vocabulary>to blow away</vocabulary> it.

If we're talking about <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>s, then we might as well be talking about <vocabulary>all people</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary>, because that's a lot of people, you know?

You know how 逃げる means "to escape"? This is the transitive version, so it means <vocabulary>to let someone escape</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to let someone go</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to set someone free</vocabulary>. You know this because you'd want to let everyone escape when the place is filled with gas (がす).

逃がす is often about purposely letting someone or something go — like setting a bird free or letting a captive escape quietly. But it can also be used in more unintentional and regretful situations, like failing to catch a criminal or missing a big opportunity.
Someone built from a <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>pattern</kanji> has a <vocabulary>small build</vocabulary>. I know lots of little old ladies that were built from these small patterns.

Something that is <kanji>transparent</kanji> enough for things (like light) to <kanji>pass through</kanji> is going <vocabulary>to be transparent</vocabulary>. In other words, it's going <vocabulary>to be clear</vocabulary>.

Unlike 透ける, which is more for things that are partially transparent due to being thin or sheer, 透き通る describes things that are totally transparent, clear, or pure — think glass, water, a cloudless sky, or even a clear and pure voice.

You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle something." When it becomes 漬かる, it means the food has reached a state where the pickling or marinating process is complete, and it's ready to eat. So this word means <vocabulary>to be well pickled</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be well marinated</vocabulary>.

If you're going to <kanji>abduct</kanji> some <kanji>noodles</kanji>, make sure it's everybody's favorite noodles, <vocabulary>ramen</vocabulary>! The other meaning of the first kanji actually makes more sense here though, because you <kanji>pull</kanji> the dough to stretch it when you make <vocabulary>ramen noodles</vocabulary>. Choose whichever meaning helps you remember it best!

This word is mostly written in kana, usually as ラーメン, but sometimes らーめん. You'll see the kanji version pretty often on packaging and menus, though, so it's worth knowing! The word is also occasionally written as らー麺 or ラー麺.

If you can read this word, you may well know what it means. It's everybody's second favorite noodle dish, <vocabulary>somen</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>somen noodles</vocabulary>, which are <vocabulary>fine white noodles</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. <kanji>Mochi</kanji> is <vocabulary>mochi</vocabulary>.
What <kanji>kill</kanji>s <kanji>insect</kanji>s with one <kanji>dose</kanji>? That's an <vocabulary>insecticide</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>pesticide</vocabulary>.

You've got a <kanji>pair</kanji> of <kanji>direction</kanji>s, so this is something that concerns <vocabulary>both parties</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>both sides</vocabulary>. Things are going in two directions, not just one! 

双方 is a relatively formal term that is often used in contexts like <vocabulary>mutual</vocabulary> agreements, negotiations, or discussions where both sides are actively engaged.

What's your favorite <kanji>fry</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji>? Surely it's <vocabulary>fried rice</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>chahan</vocabulary>! Who doesn't love fried rice?

Note that this word is commonly written in katakana as チャーハン, so you may also see it written that way on a menu or product label!

<kanji>Clothes</kanji> and <kanji>attire</kanji> makes this <vocabulary>clothing</vocabulary> at its core, but these days, it usually refers to <vocabulary>stage outfit</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>costume</vocabulary>s for performances and public events.

The kanji itself means <kanji>bustling</kanji> or <kanji>lively</kanji>, so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be bustling</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be lively</vocabulary>.

賑わう is typically used to describe bustling places or times. You might see it in phrases like 若者で賑わう街 (streets bustling with young people) or 夏に観光客で賑わう (to be crowded with tourists in summer). Since bustling places tend to flourish economically, it can also carry a nuance of prosperity and mean <vocabulary>to thrive</vocabulary>.

This shares meanings with the kanji, making it <vocabulary>bustling</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>lively</vocabulary>.

You might see 賑やか used to describe bustling and crowded city streets, a festive celebration, the sound of boisterous laughter, or even just a cheerful, animated person.
